abstract: Bank of America’s decision to hand out larger bonuses to their own bankers this time around isn’t a cure-all for the cultural rift caused by the bank’s merger with Merrill Lynch, Reuters Breakingviews says.
snippet: Bank of America’s decision to hand out larger bonuses to their own bankers this time around isn’t a cure-all for the cultural rift caused by the bank’s merger with Merrill Lynch, Reuters Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America‘s crew on Wall Street can breathe a sigh of relief, Reuters Breakingviews says. It looks like the bank is set to hand out 2007-like bonuses to all its investment bankers and traders.

headline.main: BofA’s Post-Merger Bonuses May Not Be Panacea

abstract: Wall Street has a lot to apologize for, but contrition would be more convincing if it came with accountability, The New York Times says in an editorial.
snippet: Wall Street has a lot to apologize for, but contrition would be more convincing if it came with accountability, The New York Times says in an editorial.
lead_paragraph: What’s with the apologies, The New York Times’s editorial board wants to know. Goldman Sachs’s Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that “we participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret.” That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was “doing God’s work.”

abstract: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch, emerged from relative silence to weigh in on a “too big to fail” fee, executive compensation and Goldman Sachs conspiracies in an interview with Bloomberg News.
snippet: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch, emerged from relative silence to weigh in on a “too big to fail” fee, executive compensation and Goldman Sachs conspiracies in an interview with Bloomberg News.
lead_paragraph: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch and an architect of its sale to Bank of America during the financial crisis, has lain low since he left the financial industry last year. (And with good reason, given the hail of criticism he has faced.)

headline.main: Thain Weighs In on Financial Reform

abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, took aim at Wall Street’s looming bonuses on Monday, sending letters to eight of the nation’s biggest banks demanding information on how they structured those payouts.
snippet: Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, took aim at Wall Street’s looming bonuses on Monday, sending letters to eight of the nation’s biggest banks demanding information on how they structured those payouts.
lead_paragraph: Update | 12:52 p.m. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, took aim at Wall Street’s looming bonuses on Monday, sending letters to eight of the nation’s biggest banks demanding information on how they structured those payouts.

headline.main: Cuomo Demands Bonus Data From 8 Big Banks

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Bank of New York Mellon Corp

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: The S.E.C. has sought permission from a judge to add a new charge to its existing civil lawsuit against Bank of America, adding an accusation of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill Lynch before a shareholder vote in December 2008.
snippet: The S.E.C. has sought permission from a judge to add a new charge to its existing civil lawsuit against Bank of America, adding an accusation of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill Lynch before a shareholder vote in December 2008.
lead_paragraph: Update | 7:49 p.m. Judge Jed S. Rakoff ruled on Monday that the S.E.C. cannot amend its complaint against Bank of America a second time, but can file a new complaint. More here.

headline.main: S.E.C. Seeks New Charge Against Bank of America
